questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the OSPF and IS-IS Cisco MPLS TE extensions from the left to their functional descriptions on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
TLV Type 2: includes a 8-bit default metric
TLV Type 135: support a 32-bit metric and an up/down bit
TLV Type 134: carries a 32-bit router ID for traffic engineering 
Type-10 Opaque :advertisement are flooded thoughout the
Type 22: Contains information about the link and include other sub-TLVS

From the link provided by nolbi:
TLV Type 2: 8 bits (...but only six out of eight bits are used.) 
TLV Type 134: TE Router ID , MPLS traffic engineering router ID
TLV Type 135: Provides a 32 bit metric and adds a bit for the "up/down"
Type-10 Opaque : LSAs are not flooded beyond the borders of their associated area
Type 22: The metric octets are encoded as a 24-bit unsigned integer. and i think that advertise links and sub-tlv "This will allow advertisement of a link for purposes other than building the normal Shortest Path Tree." in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5305#section-3

Why do we need to know this detail!? Such a stupid question!

I can tell you that the top MPLS engineers at one of the world's largest biggest SP do not know this.

comments.content:
Agreed. 

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5305.html
5.2.1. Sub-TLVs for the Extended IS Reachability TLV
This registry contains codepoints for sub-TLVs of TLV 22.

discussion.content: 2 and 22 are reversed. The rest are correct.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the methods of Cisco MPLS TE tunnel traffic assignment from the left onto their characteristics on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
autoroute --- Dynamic traffic tunnels
static --- Static traffic tunnels
PBTS --- Policy Based Tunnel Selection (optimise streaming services)
CBTS --- Class Based Tunnel Selection (forward traffic based on different class of service (CoS) values
are PBTS and CBTS not flipped in the provided answer?

Wow no one commented on this one? 

Both B and C work depending on the software... i wonder which the answer would be.

comments.content:
Nvm... B is correct as we are performing the command under the ospf process. 
If it was global then we would use "... igp sync ..."

discussion.content: Should be answer 'B' as Gig1 is not a L2 link and needs to be excluded
B is correct. The whole network is running IS-IS. And Gi1 is the only port of R2 on L1 adjacency, and since mpls ldp sync is enabled under the IS-IS, you have to exclude Gi1 from the sync.

comments.content:
B

Sorry, the doc formatting is bad when pasting, here goes again

"To enable LDP IGP synchronization on each interface that belongs to an OSPF or IS-IS process, enter the mpls ldp sync command. If you do not wants some of the interfaces to have LDP IGP synchronization enabled, issue the no mpls ldp igp sync command on those interfaces."

discussion.content:
To enable LDP IGP synchronization on each interface that belongs to an OSPF or IS-IS process, enter the mplsldpsync command. If you do not wantsome of the interfacesto have LDPIGPsynchronization enabled, issue the no mpls ldp igp sync command on those interfaces.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/mp_ldp/configuration/xe-17/mp-ldp-xe-17-cat8000-book/mp-ldp-igp-synch.pdf
B - it says it is need on L2 so that is what the configuration will do

Answer should be B. 
"mpls ldp sync" >> enable ldp sync on all interfaces that belong to isis.
under interface G1 issue command
"no mpls ldp igp sync" >> this will exclude that interface G1 from mpls ldp sync.

comments.content: But if you really don’t want ldp sync, then yes you can exclude the interface, but if this is a mpls P node, not sure why you would do that. If the question was a bit more clear and stated only level 2 then would choose B

discussion.content:
I’ve set this up in production and correct answer for Cisco ios is A

Igp sync will apply on interfaces only running isis.
B makes most sense, although I cannot configure mpls ldp sync under the isis routing process in GNS3...

I don't see any documentation that you have to "Exclude" on L1 IS-IS routers.
I think A is still the best answer due to its simplicity.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/mpls/configuration/guide/convert/mp_ldp_book/mp_ldp_igp_synch.html

comments.content:
Absolutely right and also I just read the question correctly for the first time.
Says for its L2 and B says no MPLS for Gig 1 which is L1.

Also, on this link is the following information:
When you issue the mpls ldp sync command, all of the interfaces that belong to an IS-IS process are enabled for LDP-IGP synchronization. To remove LDP-IGP synchronization from some interfaces, use the no form of the mpls ldp igp sync command on those interfaces. The following configuration steps show how to disable LDP-IGP synchronization from some IS-IS interfaces after they have been configured with LDP-IGP synchronization through the mpls ldp sync command:
Router> enable
Router# configure terminal
Router(config)# interface POS3/0
Router(config-if)# no mpls ldp igp sync
Router(config-if)# end

Remember that for IOS you can jump from the ISIS configuration mode directly to the interface configuration mode. So, the correct answer is B.
I dont see "none" as an option so Im sticking with A

I dont see none because I dont know how to read the diagram.
Please ignore my previous comment, Nolbi is 100% right.
Which configuration must be applied to R2 to enable LDP-IGP Sync on its L2 IS-IS adjacencies? ????

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. What type of configuration is it?

discussion.content: does anybody have an input on this?

choices.D: It is configuration that requires an explicit Cisco MPLS TE path to be configured for the tunnel to run
choices.B: It is configuration that requires a dynamic Cisco MPLS TE path to be configured for the tunnel to run
choices.A: It is configuration that requires OSPF to also be running to have optimized Cisco MPLS TE tunnels
choices.C: It is configuration for the head-end router of a Cisco MPLS TE tunnel with segment routing
